coredata.dc:description: Recently, sustainability guidelines such as the Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) or the EU Taxonomy Regulation have become legally binding, thus requiring enterprises to monitor, control and report their contributions in compliance with sustainable development goals (SDGs). Comprehensive sustainability assessment methods are, therefore, crucial for ensuring competitive advantages of enterprises in the near future. Yet, lack of tailor-made methods particularly for manufacturing SMEs is evident. To address this pathway of research, this paper proposes a comprehensive indicator scheme for measuring and monitoring sustainability performance of manufacturing SMEs aligned with the SDGs. The proposed method is based on a literature analysis of existing measurement approaches. It combines methods from quality and innovation management in a sustainability evaluation scheme especially designed for manufacturing SMEs. The method is demonstrated in excerpts from an industry case study. The preliminary results reveal plausibility of the approach towards enabling enterprises to systematically define sustainability roadmaps and conduct progress monitoring.

Introduction The relevance of sustainability in all its dimensions is becoming a key factor for enterprises, especially when it comes to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) of the United Nations (UN) [1]. There are further global initiatives focusing on sustainable transformation, inter alia, the Paris Agreement [2], the IPBES Global Assessment on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services [3], the Sixth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) [4] or the Addis Ababa Action Agenda [5]. In the European Union (EU), there are further legal framework conditions that either currently apply to the member states or will gradually come into force in the upcoming years. Based on the EU Green Deal published in 2019, which calls for, among other things, climate neutrality by 2050 and sustainable growth, Europe has a clear strategic objective to achieve its ambitious sustainability targets by the year 2050 [6]. More importantly, the introduction of the Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) for the first time legally obligates enterprises to report standardized sustainability performance [7]. Within the scope of this reporting, the declaration of EU taxonomy conformity is required. Metrics such as CO2-equivalent or energy consumption are used for this purpose [8]. The clear commitment of the EU to quantify sustainability with measurable values and with those indicators set goals for enterprises to achieve, shows that sustainability metrics are increasingly important for competitive businesses in the near future. Moreover, its large number of SMEs characterizes the manufacturing industry in Central Europe. In Germany, France, Italy, Switzerland, Hungary, and Austria, over 96% [9] of the enterprises fall into this category, according to the European SMEs definition [10]. This has implications for the implementation of sustainability reporting, i.e. the Global Reporting Initiative (GRI) provides a procedure for introducing sustainability in enterprises. However, large corporations primarily implement the regulations. As Neri et al. conclude [11], the main reason is that it requires resources and capabilities that SMEs may not have, such as time, money, knowledge, skills, support, and guidance. The GRI procedure may also not consider the specifics and needs of SMEs, e.g., their stakeholders, impacts, and motivations for sustainability reporting. Hence, a holistic, tailor-made approach for SMEs is needed to steer the way towards a sustainable transformation, especially in the European manufacturing landscape [12]. To accomplish this goal, this paper aims to provide an indicator scheme for SMEs aligned with UNÃ¢â¬â¢s SDGs, as these have a major impact at both local and global level [13]. The main objective is to design an indicator-based assessment approach, similar to existing benchmark evaluation schemes from adjacent domains such as quality management (EFQM) [14]. Pursuing this line of research, the key research question (RQ) is "How can an indicator scheme be set up, to enable manufacturing SMEs to measure and monitor their sustainability performance, based on the UNÃ¢â¬â¢s 17 SDGs?Ã¢â¬ï¿½. A review of selected publications shows that extensive research in the field of sustainability metrics or KPIs has already been conducted and the allocation to the three pillars of sustainability has taken place (e.g., Contini and Peruzzini [15]; Calzolari [14]). However, its instantiation regarding the 17 SDGs has yet to be presented in sufficient detail in the literature. This paper, therefore, contributes to this evolving research area with a specific focus towards the needs of manufacturing SMEs. The rest of the paper is structured as follows: In section 2, the state of the art is described, focusing on relevant approaches and methods to define metrics and KPIs in connection with the SDGs. Section 3 introduces the approach developed to define SDG-metrics and how they are used in a process driven sustainability monitoring. Finally, Section 4 discusses the main findings, potential limitations, and indicates future research avenues. 2. State of the Art The literature research (cf. Table 1) shows that there are already various models to measure enterprise-specific metrics in the field of sustainability. Despite merits, there is a major attention to economic factors [16] as the focus historically had mostly been on competitiveness. Most of the reviewed papers share the common goal of measuring and assessing organizational sustainability performance. Differences between these methodologies include i) specific focus areas (inter alia circular economy, industrial supply chains, performance management systems, and SDGs in the automotive industry), ii) research approach and underlying methodology (e.g. three-step methodology, literature review, and survey), and iii) application context (e.g. forest and paper sector organization, different decision-making levels, broad range of industries, and European automotive enterprises). Considering these limitations in existing frameworks, the present paper contributes to introducing a novel approach offering a comprehensive and tailor-made method for assessing SDG achievement in SMEs through the integration of value- stream-based sustainability assessment, SDGs, and SME-specific components. In the following section, this approach will be outlined. 3. Sustainability Check and Quantification Approach 3.1. Sustainability-Check approach The "Sustainability Check" approach presented in this paper records the status quo of sustainability in manufacturing enterprises in accordance with the SDGs. The focus is on enterprises that are categorized as SMEs. The approach comprises the following three main steps, picking up suitable starting points from the literature analysis, namely i) flexible value-stream aspect for a better SME fit, ii) sustainability metric approach for assessment, as well as iii) road mapping technique from innovation management. The steps are implemented in a workshop format, involving as many departments of an enterprise as possible, including but not limited to human resources, production, maintenance, and management. 3.1.1. Step 1: Value stream mapping Value stream mapping of an enterprise facilitates gaining deeper understanding of the overall production system and associated process towards identifying improvement measures. The value stream mapping is carried out on a meta-level to consider all processes from gate to gate. Performing this for each product, as in the standard value stream design approach, is not necessary within this procedure to identify potential fields of action. By having the enterprise's employees map, relevant SDGs along the value chain, every process step within the system boundaries can basically be taken into account. Through the moderation of an external, independent domain expert, holding knowledge of production systems, value stream design and sustainability, the process of self-evaluation is monitored and supported. This ensures that the group of employees does their best (critical) thinking [26] and fields of action are not intentionally defined, thus trying to avoid bias and aiming for a realistic and fair evaluation. Figure 1 illustrates the process model, the value chain created, and an exemplary assignment of the SDGs to the respective sections in the process chain. With the production processes defined and linked to the 17 impact areas of the SDGs, the impact fields are discussed in a workshop with internal stakeholders to highlight challenges along the value chain. 3.1.2. Step 2: Identifying & Assessing Sustainability Projects and Measures Systematic recording of past and current projects and associated sustainability measures enables identifying the status quo. This shows in which areas of the SDGs, projects have been realized in the enterprise and where there are still unexhausted potentials. Quantitative evaluation of these projects requires an indicator scheme, which is discussed in more detail in Section 3.2. Notably, in order to gain a comprehensive overview, a manageable but relevant stakeholder group covering employees across the departments and hierarchy levels of the enterprise is involved. This promotes diverse perspectives regarding the developed measures and projects, as well as the reduction of biases. For this reason, the chronological order of the activities is shown in a roadmap to determine the path for the enterpriseÃ¢â¬â¢s short- and long-term future. Measurable values should, therefore, be developed to identify required efforts and benefits of individual fields of activity within the enterprise. This is achieved using the SDG metrics approach, described in more detail in the section 3.2. With the identification of sustainability drivers in the value streams, challenges related to the SDGs can be raised. Figure 1 shows an example from an enterprise in the field of injection molding. The analysis highlights the high consumption of water in the cleaning process (cf. SDG 6 Ã¢â¬â Clean water and sanitation) or the lack of assistance systems in the assembly line (cf. SDG 8 Ã¢â¬â Decent work). The system boundary of the method presented here is the production site. This is because individual production sites can be compared better than several enterprises' combined sites. 3.2. Quantification Approach - Developing an SDG metric The SDG metric is needed to evaluate and assess the status of sustainability measures from step 2 of the sustainability check, and also for the definition of concrete goals for measures in the roadmap in step 3. Based on the presented literature review, specific SME requirements have been considered and an approach to match sustainability metrics with the SDGs has been chosen. For the evaluation of such a SDG metric, an example from the social dimension is presented, cf. section 3.2.2. Notably, the complete evaluation of all 17 SDGs is not the scope of this paper and is part of further and ongoing research. Further, the industrial evaluation is part of an ongoing research project that aims to build a specific SDG metric system focusing on 20 industrial partners in Austria and Germany specialized in the production and use of injection molding tools for the plastics industry. 3.2.1. Step 1: Allocation of the SDGs to the dimensions of sustainability The 17 SDGs are assigned to the respective economic, ecological, and social dimensions of sustainability. The SDG-classification is based on the "SDG Wedding Cake" classification of the 17 SDGs into the categories economy, society and environment/biosphere [28]. The wedding cake model organizes the 17 SDGs in different tiers, with the most basic needs and priorities at the bottom (e.g., eradicating poverty, no hunger) and more complex goals at the top (e.g., climate action, peace and justice). This classification facilitates understanding and communicating the overall structure and hierarchy of the SDGs, making them more accessible to a wider audience, including policymakers, businesses, and the public. Notably, the Ã¢â¬ÅSDG Wedding CakeÃ¢â¬ï¿½ should be used carefully to avoid oversimplification, misinterpretation, and neglection of the interconnectedness among SDGs. The indicator system enables quantitative recording of several metrics linked to a defined SDG. The enterprise employees involved in the process conduct the evaluation of weighting and assigned scores. This can potentially lead to vagueness and an internal enterprise bias. This is an indicator of which SDGs metrics still need to be collected and which projects should be prioritized following step 3 (cf. section 3.1) to improve sustainability performance. In step 2 of the sustainability check, the current state of sustainability projects and measures is evaluated using these metrics, thus providing two views on sustainability readiness of an enterprise, i.e. i) assessing how well the sustainability aspects are already monitored and ii) how the sustainability dimensions, according to the SDGs, are developed comparing to an industry benchmark. Details of the latter evaluation and associated results will be reported in the future works. 4. Conclusion and Future Research Agenda This paper addresses the research question of how a systematic process-driven indicator scheme can be set up for manufacturing SMEs. The goal is to measure and monitor sustainability performance, based on the SDGs, while considering the limited resources of small and medium sized enterprises. Following a literature review on related methods, a three-step approach is proposed to implement a sustainability check for manufacturing SMEs, involving mapping SDGs to the enterpriseÃ¢â¬â¢s value stream, identifying sustainability projects, and road-mapping sustainability measures. The approach of combining and normalizing multi-dimension metrics creates better comparability between enterprises. The method has been initially evaluated in a case study in a manufacturing enterprise in the field of injection molding. Despite promising findings, this paper does not yet report an evaluation of the entire method. In the current state of research, the prioritization is in the foreground. This comprises the definition of the status quo, the identification of fields of action, and the inclusion of all 17 SDGs. The intermediate findings suggest that the approach and indicator scheme can help manufacturing SMEs to contextualize and match the requirements of the SDGs for their specific production processes and businesses. The proposed approach can also help identifying SMEÃ¢â¬â¢s strengths and weaknesses in terms of sustainability performance, as well as opportunities and challenges for improvements. Furthermore, the indicator scheme can provide a quantitative and comparable measure of sustainability performance, as well as a basis for reporting and benchmarking. In sum, the paper contributes to the literature on sustainability measurement and management in manufacturing SMEs by providing a comprehensive indicator scheme based on the SDGs and a practice-oriented, systematic approach to implement it. Despite merits, the proposed approach faces certain limitations. First, the indicator scheme has far only been tested in part, i.e., for exemplary SDGs. The full evaluation of the method in a case-study has not been completed. Future research will, therefore, demonstrate the method for all SDGs and for a complete SME use-case. A further aspect is evaluating the approach with multiple SME partners, in particular to assess its generalizability. Third, the approach neither considers potential trade-offs or synergies among different SDGs or metrics, nor the dynamic and complex nature of sustainability performance over time. Future research should incorporate these aspects into our approach and indicator scheme by using more advanced methods such as multi-criteria decision analysis, system dynamics, or agent-based modeling. Future research should also focus on testing and comparing the presented approach with other methods and frameworks for sustainability measurement and management in manufacturing SMEs. In addition, the feedback from the use-cases and the stakeholders involved should be systematically analyzed to ensure the method is adjusted well enough for most SMEs and their preferences. This will likely result in iterative updates and fine-tuning of the approach. Last but not least, an important field of research is to investigate how implementation of the approach can result in better and more effective sustainability measures Ã¢â¬â ideally, resulting in guidelines in how to systematically convert the method findings to a more effective sustainability transition for SMEs. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Recently, sustainability guidelines such as the Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) or the EU Taxonomy Regulation have become legally binding, thus requiring enterprises to monitor, control and report their contributions in compliance with sustainable development goals (SDGs). Comprehensive sustainability assessment methods are, therefore, crucial for ensuring competitive advantages of enterprises in the near future. Yet, lack of tailor-made methods particularly for manufacturing SMEs is evident. To address this pathway of research, this paper proposes a comprehensive indicator scheme for measuring and monitoring sustainability performance of manufacturing SMEs aligned with the SDGs. The proposed method is based on a literature analysis of existing measurement approaches. It combines methods from quality and innovation management in a sustainability evaluation scheme especially designed for manufacturing SMEs. The method is demonstrated in excerpts from an industry case study. The preliminary results reveal plausibility of the approach towards enabling enterprises to systematically define sustainability roadmaps and conduct progress monitoring.
